This model suggests that humans have a hierarchy of needs, starting with basic physiological needs (food, shelter) and progressing to safety, love/belonging, esteem, and self-actualization.
Problems related to unmet lower-level needs (e.g., financial instability, lack of safety) are generally considered more fundamental and pressing than those related to higher-level needs (e.g., boredom, lack of purpose).
In your situation, the financial disparity you described touches on these lower level needs. If the basics are not being met by both parties, it will cause issues.
This can help distinguish between "real" problems (those impacting basic survival and security) and those arising from a desire for more abstract fulfillment.

People with an internal locus of control believe they have control over their own lives and outcomes.
Those with an external locus of control believe external forces (e.g., luck, other people) determine their fate.
Problems perceived by someone with an external locus of control might seem "manufactured" to someone with an internal locus, as they may attribute them to external factors rather than taking personal responsibility.
This can also play into the idea of learned helplessness, where a person feels as though they have no control over their outcomes, so why try.

This model describes three common roles people play in dysfunctional relationships: victim, persecutor, and rescuer.
"Manufactured" problems can often be used to perpetuate these roles, with someone playing the victim to elicit rescue or attention.
This is a common dynamic, and it is easy to fall into these roles.
Someone may be playing the victim, and you are falling into the role of rescuer by paying for everything.

These are irrational thought patterns that can lead to distorted perceptions of reality.
Examples include catastrophizing, overgeneralizing, and emotional reasoning.
Problems perceived through the lens of cognitive distortions might seem exaggerated or unfounded to others.
This would explain why someone might be having a problem that seems manufactured. They are truly experiencing the problem, but their perception of the problem is distorted.

This is a colloquial term, but it is useful.
